docs.lead_paragraph: The United States may be at the top by most economic measures, but for an important measure of social health -- teenage pregnancy and childbearing -- it moves among the poorest. American teenagers are best compared to those in the Russian federation or in depressed Eastern European countries like Bulgaria, a new study finds. Teenage pregnancy and childbearing rates here are at least four times those in France, Germany and Japan, said researchers from Alan Guttmacher Institute, which researches reproductive health.

headline.main: The Two Worlds of Teenage Pregnancy

docs.abstract: Researchers from Alan Guttmacher Institute find that US is among the worst nations when it comes to teenage pregnancy and childbearing, an important measure of social health; finds that American teenagers are best compared to those in Russian federation or in depressed Eastern European countries like Bulgaria; say that teenage pregnancy and childbearing rates in US are at least four times those in France, Germany and Japan (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: It's not just various foods that cause the tongue to experience the pleasures and discomforts of flavors. Researchers at Yale say they have proven that the four major tastes -- sweet, sour, salty and bitter -- can, under the right conditions, also be produced by changing the temperature of taste buds. Warm tastes sweet and sometimes bitter; cold can seem salty or sour.

headline.main: Acquiring a Taste for Cold Weather

docs.abstract: Researchers at Yale say they have proven that four major tastes--sweet, sour, salty and bitter--can, under the right conditions, also be produced by changing temperature of taste buds; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new team of researchers has weighed into the debate over whether infants should be routinely screened for hearing loss at birth. Although some experts believe that such testing is unwarranted, researchers from the University of Colorado at Boulder are offering evidence to the contrary.
docs.abstract: New team of researchers weighs into debate over whether infants should be routinely screened for hearing loss at birth; argue that earlier detection and action helps hearing-impaired children achieve normal language skills (S)
docs.snippet: A new team of researchers has weighed into the debate over whether infants should be routinely screened for hearing loss at birth.    Although some experts believe that such testing is unwarranted, researchers from the University of Colorado at...

docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes, it just doesn't pay to be optimistic, or, at least, overly so. A new study reports that doctors who treat terminally ill people routinely overestimate how much time their patients have left, and, as a result, may deprive them of the kind of care they need.

headline.main: Undue Optimism When Death Is Near

docs.abstract: New study finds that doctors who treat terminally ill people routinely overestimate how much time their patients have left, and, as result, may deprive them of kind of care they need (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Allergies and asthma in children are on the rise in industrialized countries and medical scientists are searching for ways to stem this mysterious trend. Doctors had long assumed that exclusive breast-feeding for at least the first six months of life and delaying the introduction of allergenic foods like peanuts, cow's milk and eggs was the best way to stave off allergies. But several new studies indicate that there are limits to the long-term effectiveness of this approach for babies most at risk for developing allergies.

headline.main: Linking Allergy, Asthma and Infant Diets

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on rise in allergies and asthma in children in industrialized countries and scientists' search for ways to stem mysterious trend; doctors have long assumed that exclusive breast-feeding for at least first six months of life and delaying introduction of allergenic foods like peanuts, cow's milk and eggs are best way to stave off allergies, but several new studies indicate that there are limits to long-term effectiveness of this approach for babies most at risk for developing allergies; allergy-preventing benefits of breast-feeding appear to depend on allergic status of mothers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Feeling hopeless is not just unpleasant: it may also be bad for the health. A study suggests that people suffering persistent periods of hopelessness may be at greater risk for hypertension, researchers at the University of Michigan report. Their study, in the latest issue of the journal Hypertension, said they had come to their conclusion after analyzing health records of 616 middle-aged men who took part in a major study in Finland.

headline.main: When Despair Invades the Blood Vessels

docs.abstract: Study of Finnish men finds that those suffering persistent periods of hopelessness may be at greater risk for hypertension (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ed Sher, a 38-year-old St. Louis lawyer, is nothing if not goal-oriented. A bit of a tennis fanatic, he has his sights set on winning the Meadowbrook Country Club Tennis Championship in August. With that goal etched in his mind, he plays several times a week and also works out with Dale Huff, owner of Nutriformance Personal Training and Sports Nutrition, a private company in St. Louis, to give him an edge over his 15 middle-aged peers.

headline.main: Amateur Athletes Turn to Pro Trainers

docs.abstract: Growing number of recreational athletes seek professional training for specific sports; photo (M)
